content: The Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004 ensures that civil rights and liberties are not compromised in homeland security efforts. It also establishes an Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties within the Department of Homeland Security. Section 705(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to report directly to the Secretary, address concerns on profiling based on race, ethnicity, or religion, and assist in developing and reviewing policies within the Department of Homeland Security. The Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties is required to assist in developing, implementing, and reviewing Department policies to ensure protection of civil rights and civil liberties. They also oversee compliance with various requirements and coordinate with other officials to address concerns related to profiling. The Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties oversees compliance with legal requirements and investigates complaints of possible abuses. They also coordinate with other officials to address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy concerns in an integrated manner. The Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties ensures compliance with legal requirements, investigates complaints of possible abuses, and coordinates with other officials to address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy concerns. Congress receives reports on programs, policies, and procedures, and investigates complaints of civil rights or civil liberties abuses. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND CIVIL LIBERTIES BY OFFICE OF INSPECTOR GENERAL. Designation and Functions of Senior Official under Homeland Security Act of 2002 amended to include oversight of civil rights and civil liberties. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security designates a senior official to coordinate investigations of abuses of civil rights and civil liberties within the department and its contractors or grantees. The Office of Inspector General oversees complaints and investigations of civil rights and civil liberties abuses within the Department of Homeland Security and its contractors or grantees. They ensure personnel are trained for effective investigations and consult with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. They ensure personnel receive training for effective investigations and consult with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties on alleged abuses and policy recommendations. They also provide information on investigation outcomes and refer matters to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. The Office of Inspector General oversees investigations of civil rights and civil liberties abuses within the Department of Homeland Security. They provide information on investigation outcomes and refer matters to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties for further action. The Office of Inspector General oversees investigations of civil rights and civil liberties abuses within the Department of Homeland Security. They handle complaints, investigate public complaints, and report weaknesses or deficiencies to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. They handle complaints, investigate public complaints, and report weaknesses or deficiencies to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. Additionally, there is a Privacy Officer designated in Section 5. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a Privacy Officer who reports directly to the Secretary. The Privacy Officer is responsible for coordinating with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to ensure that programs, policies, and procedures involving civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy are addressed comprehensively and reported to Congress.
